results.title: The Dead bird
results.creator_credit: Oxford Films (U.S.), Moreland-Latchford Productions and Graham Parker
results.brief_description: A short story by Margaret Wise Brown which encourages young readers to expect a rewarding experience from reading and to write a story themselves from casual incidents in their own lives. The theme of the film, the dead bird, also lends itself to discussion about the naturalness of death, leading to an appraisal of the essential values in living

results.title: The Dead
results.creator_credit: Vestron Pictures, Zenith, Channel Four, Delta Films, Liffey Films, Wieland Schulz-Keil, Chris Sievernich and John Huston
results.brief_description: It is January 6, 1904, on a snowy night in Dublin; a festive night at the Morkan house, as Miss Kate, Miss Julia and their niece Mary Jane prepare for their annual party. In this his last film, John Huston, captures the wonderful mix of comedy and quiet tragedy portrayed in James Joyce’s short stroy from “The Dubliners”. As the evening progresses, the characters subtly betray their secret lives, culminating in the moment when Gabriel, the calm observer, learns a secret that will change his life forever. A beautiful, eloquent film.

results.title: The de' Medici kitchen: a culinary journey
results.brief_description: Showcases the de’ Medici estate of Coltibuorno in Italy and their various farming activities. Examines food from the region of the estate and food associated with the farm’s produce. Describes the importance of food and dining in the Italian culture. Explores the Coltibourno region and explains regional traditions.

results.title: The Daytrippers
results.creator_credit: Fiasco Photoplays, Trick Film Studios, Nancy Tenenbaum, Steven Soderbergh and Greg Mottola
results.brief_description: This low budget gem is a charming take on the road movie genre which balances equal amounts of humour and melancholy as it traces a day in the life of a middle class American family. The films events are set off by a love letter that is discovered one morning by Eliza D’Amico (Hope Davis), which is addressed to her husband Louis (Stanley Tucci) and is signed, ‘Forever Sandy’. The distraught Eliza enlists the advice of her close knit family who decide the best course of action is to head into the city and confront Louis at work. So Eliza, her parents, her younger sister Jo (Parker Posey), and her sister’s bookish boyfriend, Carl (Liev Schreiber), all jump in the family car and head to Manhattan. The film then takes on a classic road movie structure as they meet various people on their trip, suffer a few mishaps, and have their own personal revelations along the way. The script by first time director Greg Mottola is full of tender observations and sharp one liners, while the film boasts a wonderful ensemble cast which also includes Pat McNamara, Annie Meara and Campbell Scott.

results.title: The Days the world went mad
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Max Morgan-Witts
results.brief_description: A documentary of natural disasters compiled from film footage gathered from all over the world. Earthquakes, tidal waves, eruptions, tornadoes and hurricanes are all recorded. Includes unique footage of the Alaskan earthquake.

results.title: The Days of Whiskey Gap
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Wolf Koenig, Roman Kroitor and Colin Low
results.brief_description: The 1870s were years of grave crises in the Canadian West. American whiskey traders were victimizing the Indians. Chief Sitting Bull and his Sioux warriors, fresh from their victory over the US Cavalry, were camped near the Cypress Hills, and the stage was set for tragedy. In 1873, the North-West Mounted Police were established to maintain law and order in the newly acquired North-West Territories. The following summer a courageous expedition trekked 800 miles from Fort Dufferin, south of Winnipeg, to Fort Whoopup, near present-day Lethbridge. The force raised the flag and proclaimed the Queen’s law, ensuring that the Canadian West would not become a lawless American-style frontier. This film brings to life some of the legends of the men in the scarlet tunics.

results.title: The Daylight moon: a film about the poet Les Murray
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone Productions, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Don Featherstone
results.brief_description: If there were such a thing, Les Murray would be the Poet Laureate of Australia. In this amusing, lyrical documentary, Don Featherstone has succeeded in capturing the essence of one of our finest poets, a man totally at home in the country round Bunyah N.S.W., farming for a living and writing poems. Interviews with the endearing Les Murray are interspersed with readings of his poems set to suitably beautiful images of the area and people which inspired them. Winner of the Gold Plaque, Chicago International Film Festival 1991.

results.title: The Day the sun turned cold = Tianguo niezi
results.creator_credit: Pineast Pictures, Ann Hui and Yim Ho
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, this beautifully presented and directed suspenseful drama tells the bizarre tale of Guan Jing a young man who one day walks into his local police station and demands an investigation into the death of his father, who he believes was murdered by his mother 10 years earlier. Guan Jing is at first met with an amount of scepticism by the Captain of Police but gradually the Captain finds himself drawn into this story of intrigue and betrayal. Using flashbacks the audience is taken on a journey of discovery into the lives and emotions of Guan Jing, his mother and his father, superbly played by Tao Chung Wah, Si Ching Gao Wa and Ma Jing Wu respectively. The film does moves slowly, but the atmospheric cinematography of blues and misty whites, combined with an intense and involved story of murder, passion and family relationships will keep you fascinated to the end. Cinematography by Ho Yung. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Day the earth stood still
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Julian Blaustein and Robert Wise
results.brief_description: Based on a story by Harry Bates, this tale of an invasion of earth by a single spaceship from a planet in outer space is a classic sci-fi movie from the 1950s. The alien ship has two occupants, an eight-foot robot, and a humanoid being. They have come to warn the earth’s people that all other inhabited planets have banded together into a peaceful organisation and that inter-planetary peace is being threatened by the wars of the earthlings, and if this peace is disturbed, the inter-planetary UN is prepared to blast the earth out of the universe. The messenger spacecraft lands in downtown Washington and creates great fear throughout the world and the US rolls out their army tanks, howitzers and any other weapon they can find to guard the robot at the ship. The humanoid leaves the ship to hide among the people and find out what they are really like. Starring Michael Rennie and Patricia Neal, this film will not dazzle with its special effects (which by today’s standards are primitive to say the least) but the message for world peace and international understanding is as pertinent today as it was in the post-Hiroshima 1950s.

results.title: The Day off
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Derek Lamb and Sidney Goldsmith
results.brief_description: A day off allows us from routine existence, but it also prepares us for re-entering the workday world. In this animated film people relaxing on a beach are constantly being reminded of tragic events happening elsewhere. By the end of the day they are able to return to the real world and continue to ‘function’. (Awards: Melbourne)
